an9.6:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi …pe… āyasmā sāriputto etadavoca:

an9.6:2.1.eng: “Reverends, you should distinguish two two kinds of individual:

an9.6:2.2.eng: those you should associate with, and those you shouldn’t associate with.

an9.6:2.3.eng: You should distinguish two kinds of robes:

an9.6:2.4.eng: those you should wear, and those you shouldn’t wear.

an9.6:2.5.eng: You should distinguish two kinds of almsfood:

an9.6:2.6.eng: that which you should eat, and that which you shouldn’t eat.

an9.6:2.7.eng: You should distinguish two kinds of lodging:

an9.6:2.8.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.

an9.6:2.9.eng: You should distinguish two kinds of village or town:

an9.6:2.10.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.

an9.6:2.11.eng: You should distinguish two kinds of country:

an9.6:2.12.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.

an9.6:3.1.eng: You should distinguish two two kinds of individual:

an9.6:3.2.eng: those you should associate with, and those you shouldn’t associate with.’

an9.6:3.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an9.6:3.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an9.6:3.4.eng: Well, should you know of an individual:

an9.6:3.5.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
an9.6:3.5.eng: ‘When I associate with this individual, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.

an9.6:3.6.pli: ye ca kho me pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā te ca kasirena samudāgacchanti;
an9.6:3.6.eng: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.

an9.6:3.7.pli: yassa camhi atthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito so ca me sāmaññattho na bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchatī’ti, tenāvuso, puggalena so puggalo rattibhāgaṃ vā divasabhāgaṃ vā saṅkhāpi anāpucchā pakkamitabbaṃ nānubandhitabbo.
an9.6:3.7.eng: And the goal of the ascetic life for which I went forth from the lay life to homelessness is not being fully developed.’ In this case you should leave that individual at that very time of the day or night, without asking. You shouldn’t follow them.

an9.6:4.1.eng: Whereas, should you know of an individual:

an9.6:4.2.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
an9.6:4.2.eng: ‘When I associate with this individual, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.

an9.6:4.3.pli: ye ca kho me pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā te ca appakasirena samudāgacchanti;
an9.6:4.3.eng: But the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are easy to come by.

an9.6:4.4.pli: yassa camhi atthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito so ca me sāmaññattho na bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchatī’ti, tenāvuso, puggalena so puggalo saṅkhāpi anāpucchā pakkamitabbaṃ nānubandhitabbo.
an9.6:4.4.eng: However, the goal of the ascetic life for which I went forth from the lay life to homelessness is not being fully developed.’ In this case you should leave that individual after reflecting, without asking. You shouldn’t follow them.

an9.6:5.1.eng: Well, should you know of an individual:

an9.6:5.2.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti;
an9.6:5.2.eng: ‘When I associate with this individual, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.

an9.6:5.3.pli: ye ca kho me pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā te ca kasirena samudāgacchanti;
an9.6:5.3.eng: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.

an9.6:5.4.pli: yassa camhi atthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito so ca me sāmaññattho bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchatī’ti, tenāvuso, puggalena so puggalo saṅkhāpi anubandhitabbo na pakkamitabbaṃ.
an9.6:5.4.eng: But the goal of the ascetic life for which I went forth from the lay life to homelessness is being fully developed.’ In this case you should follow that individual after appraisal. You shouldn’t leave them.

an9.6:6.1.eng: Whereas, should you know of an individual:

an9.6:6.2.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti;
an9.6:6.2.eng: ‘When I associate with this individual, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.

an9.6:6.3.pli: ye ca kho me pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā samudānetabbā cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā te ca appakasirena samudāgacchanti;
an9.6:6.3.eng: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are easy to come by.

an9.6:6.4.pli: yassa camhi atthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito so ca me sāmaññattho bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchatī’ti, tenāvuso, puggalena so puggalo yāvajīvaṃ anubandhitabbo na pakkamitabbaṃ api panujjamānena.
an9.6:6.4.eng: And the goal of the ascetic life for which I went forth from the lay life to homelessness is being fully developed.’ In this case you should follow that individual. You shouldn’t leave them, even if they send you away.

an9.6:6.5.eng: ‘You should distinguish two kinds of individual:

an9.6:6.6.eng: those you should associate with, and those you shouldn’t associate with.’

an9.6:6.7.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an9.6:6.7.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an9.6:7.1.eng: ‘You should distinguish two kinds of robes:

an9.6:7.2.eng: those you should wear, and those you shouldn’t wear.’

an9.6:7.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an9.6:7.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an9.6:7.4.eng: Well, should you know of a robe:

an9.6:7.5.pli: ‘idaṃ kho me cīvaraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpaṃ cīvaraṃ na sevitabbaṃ.
an9.6:7.5.eng: ‘When I wear this robe, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not wear that kind of robe.

an9.6:7.6.eng: Whereas, should you know of a robe:

an9.6:7.7.pli: ‘idaṃ kho me cīvaraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpaṃ cīvaraṃ sevitabbaṃ.
an9.6:7.7.eng: ‘When I wear this robe, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should wear that kind of robe.

an9.6:7.8.eng: ‘You should distinguish two kinds of robes:

an9.6:7.9.eng: those you should wear, and those you shouldn’t wear.’

an9.6:7.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an9.6:7.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an9.6:8.1.eng: ‘You should distinguish two kinds of almsfood:

an9.6:8.2.eng: that which you should eat, and that which you shouldn’t eat.’

an9.6:8.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an9.6:8.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an9.6:8.4.eng: Well, should you know of almsfood:

an9.6:8.5.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me piṇḍapātaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpo piṇḍapāto na sevitabbo.
an9.6:8.5.eng: ‘When I eat this almsfood, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not eat that kind of almsfood.

an9.6:8.6.eng: Whereas, should you know of almsfood:

an9.6:8.7.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me piṇḍapātaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpo piṇḍapāto sevitabbo.
an9.6:8.7.eng: ‘When I eat this almsfood, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should eat that kind of almsfood.

an9.6:8.8.eng: ‘You should distinguish two kinds of almsfood:

an9.6:8.9.eng: that which you should eat, and that which you shouldn’t eat.’

an9.6:8.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an9.6:8.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an9.6:9.1.eng: ‘You should distinguish two kinds of lodging:

an9.6:9.2.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an9.6:9.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an9.6:9.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an9.6:9.4.eng: Well, should you know of a lodging:

an9.6:9.5.pli: ‘idaṃ kho me senāsanaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpaṃ senāsanaṃ na sevitabbaṃ.
an9.6:9.5.eng: ‘When I frequent this lodging, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not frequent that kind of lodging.

an9.6:9.6.eng: Whereas, should you know of a lodging:

an9.6:9.7.pli: ‘idaṃ kho me senāsanaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpaṃ senāsanaṃ sevitabbaṃ.
an9.6:9.7.eng: ‘When I frequent this lodging, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should frequent that kind of lodging.

an9.6:9.8.eng: ‘You should distinguish two kinds of lodging:

an9.6:9.9.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an9.6:9.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an9.6:9.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an9.6:10.1.eng: ‘You should distinguish two kinds of village or town:

an9.6:10.2.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an9.6:10.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an9.6:10.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an9.6:10.4.eng: Well, should you know of a village or town:

an9.6:10.5.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me gāmanigamaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpo gāmanigamo na sevitabbo.
an9.6:10.5.eng: ‘When I frequent this village or town, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not frequent that kind of village or town.

an9.6:10.6.eng: Whereas, should you know of a village or town:

an9.6:10.7.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me gāmanigamaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpo gāmanigamo sevitabbo.
an9.6:10.7.eng: ‘When I frequent this village or town, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should frequent that kind of village or town.

an9.6:10.8.eng: ‘You should distinguish two kinds of village or town:

an9.6:10.9.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an9.6:10.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an9.6:10.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an9.6:11.1.eng: ‘You should distinguish two kinds of country:

an9.6:11.2.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an9.6:11.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an9.6:11.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an9.6:11.4.eng: Well, should you know of a country:

an9.6:11.5.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me janapadapadesaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpo janapadapadeso na sevitabbo.
an9.6:11.5.eng: ‘When I frequent this country, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not frequent that kind of country.

an9.6:11.6.eng: Whereas, should you know of a country:

an9.6:11.7.pli: ‘imaṃ kho me janapadapadesaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpo janapadapadeso sevitabbo.
an9.6:11.7.eng: ‘When I frequent this country, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should frequent that kind of country.

an9.6:11.8.eng: ‘You should distinguish two kinds of country:

an9.6:11.9.eng: those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.’

an9.6:11.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttan”ti.
an9.6:11.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”

an9.61:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, anupubbanirodho vutto bhagavatā”ti?
an9.61:1.2.eng: What is the progressive cessation that the Buddha spoke of?”

an9.61:2.1.pli: “Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.61:2.1.eng: “First, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures … enters and remains in the first absorption.

an9.61:2.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, anupubbanirodho vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena …pe….
an9.61:2.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of progressive cessation in a qualified sense. …

an9.61:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
an9.61:3.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

an9.61:3.2.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, anupubbanirodho vutto bhagavatā nippariyāyenā”ti.
an9.61:3.2.eng: To this extent the Buddha spoke of progressive cessation in a definitive sense.”

an9.62:1.1.pli: “Nava, bhikkhave, dhamme appahāya abhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an9.62:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, without giving up nine things you can’t realize perfection.

an9.62:1.3.pli: Rāgaṃ, dosaṃ, mohaṃ, kodhaṃ, upanāhaṃ, makkhaṃ, paḷāsaṃ, issaṃ, macchariyaṃ—
an9.62:1.3.eng: Greed, hate, delusion, anger, acrimony, disdain, contempt, jealousy, and stinginess.

an9.62:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, nava dhamme appahāya abhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an9.62:1.4.eng: Without giving up these nine things you can’t realize perfection.

an9.62:2.1.pli: Nava, bhikkhave, dhamme pahāya bhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an9.62:2.1.eng: After giving up nine things you can realize perfection.

an9.62:2.3.pli: Rāgaṃ, dosaṃ, mohaṃ, kodhaṃ, upanāhaṃ, makkhaṃ, paḷāsaṃ, issaṃ, macchariyaṃ—
an9.62:2.3.eng: Greed, hate, delusion, anger, acrimony, disdain, contempt, jealousy, and stinginess.

an9.62:2.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, nava dhamme pahāya bhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātun”ti.
an9.62:2.4.eng: After giving up these nine things you can realize the fruit of perfection.”

an9.63:0.3.eng: Weaknesses in Training and Mindfulness Meditation

an9.63:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five weaknesses when you’re training.

an9.63:1.3.eng: Killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and consuming beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an9.63:1.4.eng: These are the five weaknesses when you’re training.

an9.63:2.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ sikkhādubbalyānaṃ pahānāya cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā.
an9.63:2.1.eng: To give up these five weaknesses in your training you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

an9.63:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
an9.63:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

an9.63:2.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

an9.63:2.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind …

an9.63:2.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
an9.63:2.6.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

an9.63:2.7.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ sikkhādubbalyānaṃ pahānāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.63:2.7.eng: To give up those five weaknesses in your training you should develop these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

an9.64:1.3.eng: Sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

an9.64:2.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ nīvaraṇānaṃ pahānāya cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā.
an9.64:2.1.eng: To give up these five hindrances you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

an9.64:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
an9.64:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

an9.64:2.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

an9.64:2.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind …

an9.64:2.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
an9.64:2.6.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

an9.64:2.7.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ nīvaraṇānaṃ pahānāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.64:2.7.eng: To give up those five hindrances you should develop these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

an9.65:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

an9.65:1.3.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
an9.65:1.3.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

an9.65:1.7.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
an9.65:1.7.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

an9.65:1.8.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

an9.65:2.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ kāmaguṇānaṃ pahānāya …pe… ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.65:2.1.eng: To give up these five kinds of sensual stimulation you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …”

an9.66:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five grasping aggregates.

an9.66:1.3.eng: The grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

an9.66:1.4.eng: These are the five grasping aggregates.

an9.66:2.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ pahānāya …pe… ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.66:2.1.eng: To give up these five grasping aggregates you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …”

an9.67:1.3.eng: Substantialist view, doubt, misapprehension of precepts and observances, sensual desire, and ill will.

an9.67:1.4.eng: These are the five lower fetters.

an9.67:2.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ pahānāya …pe… ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.67:2.1.eng: To give up these five lower fetters you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …”

an9.68:1.3.eng: Hell, the animal realm, the ghost realm, humanity, and the gods.

an9.68:2.1.pli: Imāsaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ gatīnaṃ pahānāya …pe… ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.68:2.1.eng: To give up these five destinations you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …”

an9.69:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of stinginess.

an9.69:1.3.eng: Stinginess with dwellings, families, material things, praise, and the teaching.

an9.69:1.4.eng: These are the five kinds of stinginess.

an9.69:2.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ macchariyānaṃ pahānāya …pe… ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.69:2.1.eng: To give up these five kinds of stinginess you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …”

an9.7:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
an9.7:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

an9.7:1.2.pli: Atha kho sutavā paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an9.7:1.2.eng: Then the wanderer Sutavā went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an9.7:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sutavā paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an9.7:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

an9.7:2.1.pli: “Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ bhagavā idheva rājagahe viharāmi giribbaje.
an9.7:2.1.eng: “Sir, this one time the Buddha was staying right here in Rājagaha, the Mountainfold.

an9.7:2.2.pli: Tatra me, bhante, bhagavato sammukhā sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:
an9.7:2.2.eng: There I heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:

an9.7:2.3.pli: ‘yo so, sutavā, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so pañca ṭhānāni ajjhācarituṃ—
an9.7:2.3.eng: ‘A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in five respects.

an9.7:2.4.pli: abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇaṃ jīvitā voropetuṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādātuṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevituṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sampajānamusā bhāsituṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sannidhikārakaṃ kāme paribhuñjituṃ seyyathāpi pubbe agāriyabhūto’ti.
an9.7:2.4.eng: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they did as a layperson.’

an9.7:2.5.pli: Kacci metaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sussutaṃ suggahitaṃ sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritan”ti?
an9.7:2.5.eng: I trust I properly heard, learned, applied the mind, and remembered that from the Buddha?”

an9.7:3.1.pli: “Taggha te etaṃ, sutavā, sussutaṃ suggahitaṃ sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritaṃ.
an9.7:3.1.eng: “Indeed, Sutavā, you properly heard, learned, applied the mind, and remembered that.

an9.7:3.2.pli: Pubbe cāhaṃ, sutavā, etarahi ca evaṃ vadāmi:
an9.7:3.2.eng: In the past, as today, I say this:

an9.7:3.3.pli: ‘yo so bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so nava ṭhānāni ajjhācarituṃ—
an9.7:3.3.eng: ‘A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in nine respects.

an9.7:3.4.pli: abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇaṃ jīvitā voropetuṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādātuṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevituṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sampajānamusā bhāsituṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sannidhikārakaṃ kāme paribhuñjituṃ seyyathāpi pubbe agāriyabhūto, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu chandāgatiṃ gantuṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu dosāgatiṃ gantuṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu mohāgatiṃ gantuṃ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu bhayāgatiṃ gantuṃ’.
an9.7:3.4.eng: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they did as a layperson. And they can’t make decisions prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, or cowardice.’

an9.7:3.5.pli: Pubbe cāhaṃ, sutavā, etarahi ca evaṃ vadāmi:
an9.7:3.5.eng: In the past, as today, I say this:

an9.7:3.6.pli: ‘yo so bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so imāni nava ṭhānāni ajjhācaritun’”ti.
an9.7:3.6.eng: ‘A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in these nine respects.’”

an9.70:1.3.eng: Desire for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, desire for rebirth in the formless realm, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance.

an9.70:1.4.eng: These are the five higher fetters.

an9.70:2.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ pahānāya …pe… ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.70:2.1.eng: To give up these five higher fetters you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …”

an9.71:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are five kinds of hard-heartedness.

an9.71:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati.
an9.71:1.3.eng: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence.

an9.71:1.4.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
an9.71:1.4.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

an9.71:1.5.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, ayaṃ paṭhamo cetokhilo.
an9.71:1.5.eng: This is the first kind of hard-heartedness.

an9.71:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhamme kaṅkhati …pe…
an9.71:2.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching …

an9.71:2.4.pli: sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto.
an9.71:2.4.eng: A mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.

an9.71:2.5.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
an9.71:2.5.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

an9.71:2.6.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, ayaṃ pañcamo cetokhilo.
an9.71:2.6.eng: This is the fifth kind of hard-heartedness.

an9.71:3.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ cetokhilānaṃ pahānāya …pe… ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.71:3.1.eng: To give up these five kinds of hard-heartedness you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …”
